issue.title: Claude 4.5 Sonnet Vulnerability Resolution Rollout Plan

comment.body:
Small status update: I’ve created https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/213193+s. This MR is now in review.

I’ve put the change behind a feature flag so we have more control. The idea was: if it’s behind a FF, we can enable it on a test project in production, check if everything behaves correctly, and then roll it out further. I have limited experience testing Claude versions this way, so I wanted to check with you folks if is this indeed how we can approach it. 

/cc @mbenayoun @wortschi @ajbiton @julianthome

I reviewed this merge request and identified a critical documentation issue that appears multiple times. I left recommendations regarding a circular reference problem where the documentation links to the current MR (214030) before it's merged, creating a logical inconsistency. I estimate there is a small amount of work required to resolve this by either updating the reference to point to the correct MR or restructuring when this documentation update is merged.

The documentation is referencing the current MR (214030) before it's merged. This creates a circular reference where the documentation links to the very MR that's adding the documentation. The link should either reference a different MR that actually enables the feature, or this documentation update should be made in a separate MR after this one is merged.

The documentation is referencing the current MR (214030) before it's merged. This creates a circular reference where the documentation links to the very MR that's adding the documentation. The link should either reference a different MR that actually enables the feature, or this documentation update should be made in a separate MR after this one is merged.

The documentation is referencing the current MR (214030) before it's merged. This creates a circular reference where the documentation links to the very MR that's adding the documentation. The link should either reference a different MR that actually enables the feature, or this documentation update should be made in a separate MR after this one is merged.

issue.title: Component usage details in catalog resource view

pull_request.title: CI: download fresh fast quarantine file on retry

comment.body:
> just download the manifest for every test job like the E2E tests do (it's only 141 bytes)

I'm torn on this one. My main fear is that those add-ons tend to stay for a very long time, and we really should reduce our CI costs overall.

If we assume 200 CI jobs for RSpec, and that we have 20k pipelines per month on canonical, this gives us 4 million API calls per month for fetching that file.

TBH, it might be nothing based to the number of API calls we're already making in pipelines (I don't have data on this), but it still feels like a big number for a file we'll so rarely use on those 4 million CI jobs.

> improve the documentation in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/engineering-productivity/fast-quarantine/-/blob/main/README.md?ref_type=heads to be very clear about what steps to take to retry a job with a fast-quarantined step/re-communicate the steps.

This sounds like a good start to me. It's a boring solution, and it would be effective enough for those cases.

Basically, when we fast-quarantine any test, we should communicate it was the case, and provide instructions on how to retry those jobs/pipelines.

I could also imagine being more precise in future iterations, and have an automation sending this message for the pipelines that failed due to that very test (we do have the data in ClickHouse for tests that failed and the associated pipelines/merge requests).

Let me know your thoughts on this!

comment.body: Thanks @anna_vovchenko! I''ve added myself to the issue and we can continue discussing there :handshake:

@jannik_lehmann I believe you are familiar with this part of the codebase, mind giving this a look? Honestly, I'm not 100% sure in which cases `value` would not be a numeric value :thinking: 

It only occurred to me that there's an edge case where destructuring would raise an error if `performance.getEntriesByName('prompt-to-response')` is empty. But as mentioned in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/580794 we are seeing a couple of `value should be an instance of Integer, Float (Gitlab::Tracking::EventValidator::InvalidPropertyTypeError)` errors in Sentry

pull_request.title: UI elements to control tags sort order added

comment.body: okay i will take reference of that and make changes

a possible quick fix/test:

```
--- a/lib/gitlab/github_import/representation/diff_note.rb
+++ b/lib/gitlab/github_import/representation/diff_note.rb
@@ -92,7 +92,15 @@ def line_code
           # so it is set as the first line for any type of file (image, binary, text)
           return Gitlab::Git.diff_line_code(file_path, 1, 1) if on_file?

-          diff_line = Gitlab::Diff::Parser.new.parse(diff_hunk.lines).to_a.last
+          # Use .to_s to safely handle nil diff_hunks without crashing.
+          diff_line = Gitlab::Diff::Parser.new.parse(diff_hunk.to_s.lines).to_a.last
+
+          # If no diff_line is found, fallback to end_line for accuracy.
+          unless diff_line
+            fallback_line = end_line || 1
+            return Gitlab::Git.diff_line_code(file_path, fallback_line, fallback_line)
+          end
+
           Gitlab::Git.diff_line_code(file_path, diff_line.new_pos, diff_line.old_pos)
         end

diff --git a/spec/lib/gitlab/github_import/representation/diff_note_spec.rb b/spec/lib/gitlab/github_import/representation/diff_note_spec.rb
index 4295627ff4f1..0e7e6b312d63 100644
--- a/spec/lib/gitlab/github_import/representation/diff_note_spec.rb
+++ b/spec/lib/gitlab/github_import/representation/diff_note_spec.rb
@@ -153,6 +153,14 @@
           expect(note.line_code).to eq('8ec9a00bfd09b3190ac6b22251dbb1aa95a0579d_2_2')
         end

+        context 'when diff_hunk is missing' do
+          it 'falls back to end_line without raising' do
+            note = described_class.new(diff_hunk: nil, file_path: 'README.md', end_line: 7)
+
+            expect(note.line_code).to eq(Gitlab::Git.diff_line_code('README.md', 7, 7))
+          end
+        end
+
         context 'when comment on file' do
           it 'generates line code for first line' do
             note = described_class.new(diff_hunk: '', file_path: 'README.md', subject_type: 'file')
```

issue.title: Static reachability is being propagated after the ingestion

comment.body:
Thanks @zmartins for the details, I am reviewing and testing that fix will get back on the MR.

> Although the change behind `dependency_scanning_sbom_scan_api` isn't the cause of this issue, it adds some complexity to the whole workflow of ingestion between security reports and sbom reports. As although it provides a job with information to generate a `gl-dependency-scanning-report.json`, this file won't work as a security report as those vulnerabilities won't be ingested thus won't be by [`VulnerabilityData`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/services/sbom/ingestion/vulnerability_data.rb).

Also can you clarify if this is a changed behaviour after `dependency_scanning_sbom_scan_api` was introduced?

issue.title: Service Desk outbound email failures via external SMTP (Microsoft 365) — intermittent (~20% fail)

comment.body:
@iimama @acroitor for custom email we use the default timeout we use for all outgoing emails, which is `5` seconds. For the custom email verification email we extend this limit to `7` seconds. 

AFAIK this is not configurable for customers on self-managed, so a fixed constant for all customers.

I'm also not aware of any throttling or filtering. I also don't think we have noteable spikes of traffic that go to MS servers.

Usually `5` seconds should be enough for an enterprise grade email provider. Of course it might depend on whether the email contained attachments etc. For Service Desk we send native attachments instead of links for email sizes smaller than `10MB`.

Would we be able to verify if these problems occur when sending emails with attachments?

In my mind we have a couple of options:
1. Increase overall timeout to something like 7 seconds.
2. Increase timeout limit to say 10 when its a service desk email with attachments.
3. Don't do anything. 

I don't think 1) is a huge problem. Most of the time email delivery will be fast so this only impacts very slow responses and potentially emails with larger attachments. 2) is ideal but more work but should be doable. I'm not confident with 3).

WDYT about going with 1) for now and increase the limit to `7` seconds for all emails using the custom email feature? The customer could then further monitor and we could opt in to 2) if it didn't help.

BTW getting this error doesn't necessarily mean the email wasn't delivered. Maybe the answer from the mail server didn't get through in time etc. But I agree it's not ideal.
